bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The South East Coal Company operated in a town called Seco in Letcher County, Kentucky from 1915 until 1957. Seco is an acronym for South East Coal Company. Both the town and the company were incorporated in 1915 by A.D. Smith and Harry LaViers of the South East Coal Company, marked by the establishment of a first class post office. However, the town existed prior to the arrival of the South East Coal Company; the coal rights to the land surrounding the town were sold in 1898 according to courthouse records. Oral histories from town residents note that prior to both the town's and the company's incorporation that the river had already been turned, with an office building and three sawmills installed as early as 1905-1910. In addition to their operations at Seco, the company operated a mine and coal camp at the other end of their land holdings called Millstone. Coal Campus USA cites a December 1, 1925 article in The Coal Trade Bulletin in which the company notably only hired white laborers and never had any labor troubles in the first ten years of its existence. Additionally, the bulletin highlighted how well built, well placed and well maintained the company houses were, that there was not a police force for the town, and that such features demonstrated the character of the management, as well as the congenial conditions which simple discipline creates and maintains.
Kentucky Coal Education. (n.d.). Seco, Kentucky Letcher County. http://www.coaleducation.org/coalhistory/coaltowns/seco.htm

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The South East Coal Company records (dated 1905-1982, undated; 7.16 cubic feet, 14 boxes, 16 items, 18 reels) comprise the company's daybooks from 1914-1945 and ledgers from 1915-1945, as well as moving images from 1950-1951, and photographs from 1905-1982. The daybooks note South East Coal Company's accounts payable and received from November 1914 through December 1945, and the ledgers document South East Coal Company's annual accounts from January 1915 through December 1945. The moving images document various components of life associated with the South East Coal Company, from reels depicting families, sporting events, domestic and international vacations, holiday celebrations, and gardens. The photographs depict locations such as Millstone, Jenkins, Thealka, Irvine, Auxier, Elkhorn, Seco, and Paintsville, Kentucky, various parts of South East Coal Company's facilities, including the surrounding area, transportation, office operations, mine mechanical works, and other company memorabilia, general equipment, miscellaneous papers, and identified people and workers.

did.abstract: These daybooks note South East Coal Company's accounts payable and received from November 1914 through December 1945.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These daybooks note South East Coal Company's accounts payable and received from November 1914 through December 1945. Included are South East's operating expenses for their mines and their compnay stores at Seco and Millstone. "Office Payroll," "Workers' Payroll," "Rent," expenses accrued for "Wagon" and "Railroad Maintenance," "Houses," "Local Sales," "Stable and Livestock," and "Miscellaneous Expenses" are recorded. The daybooks also note the expenditures for victims of mining accidents, mining supplies (such as powder and explosives), and payments to local schools and churches. The books reveal that South East conducted business with local companies in nearby Hazard as well as regional cities such as: Lexington and Louisville, Kentucky and Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. The company also traded with businesses in east coast cities such as Philadelphia. The books also document South East's transactions with several notable companies: Sears, Roebuck, and Company, Standard Film Service, Western Union Telegram, and the Louisville and Nashville Railroad.

did.abstract: These ledgers document South East Coal Company's annual accounts from January 1915 through December 1945.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These ledgers document South East Coal Company's annual accounts from January 1915 through December 1945. Included are South East's annual capital stock accounts, profit/ loss account balances, workers' salaries and insurance accounts, and loans and taxes accrued. Accounting for the expenses of the "SECO/ Millstone Store," "Houses and Buildings," "Operating," "School House," "Amusement Hall," "Stable and Livestock," "Powder and Explosives," and expenses for their mines (cars, rails, and motors) are also noted. The ledgers reveal that South East conducted business with companies located in various cities such as: Lexington, Kentucky; Cincinnati, Ohio; and Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The ledgers also note that South East conducted business with various notable companies including Standard Oil, Kentucky and West Virginia Power, Connecticut Electric Company, Elkhorn Coal Company, Coca-Cola Bottling, Dixie Ice Cream, Louisville News, Hazard Ice Cream, Aetna Life Insurance, and Cincinnati Electric.
